unnormalised: So, someone asked about my experience with coaching classes for competitive exams. It’s a journey, let me tell you! I’m from a small town near Guwahati, and the pressure to crack the JEE after 12th was immense. Everyone was joining coaching centres, and the ‘toppers’ were all prepping with Aakash or FIITJEE Delhi since class 11th.
normalised: So, someone asked about my experience with coaching classes for competitive exams. It’s a journey, let me tell you! I’m from a small town near Guwahati, and the pressure to crack the J-E-E after twelfth was immense. Everyone was joining coaching centers, and the ‘toppers’ were all prepping with Aakash or F-I-I-T-J-E-E Delhi since class eleventh.

unnormalised: My parents, bless their hearts, wanted the best for me, so after my class 10th boards, they enrolled me in a local coaching centre – ‘Sharma Tutorials.’ It wasn't as fancy as the national brands, but Mr. Sharma sir was a legend. He’d solved JEE problems in his head, apparently. Classes were 6 days a week, from 4:00 PM to 8:00 PM, after school. Tough, but manageable.
normalised: My parents, bless their hearts, wanted the best for me, so after my class tenth boards, they enrolled me in a local coaching center – ‘Sharma Tutorials.’ It wasn't as fancy as the national brands, but Mister Sharma sir was a legend. He’d solved J-E-E problems in his head, apparently. Classes were six days a week, from four P-M to eight P-M, after school. Tough, but manageable.

unnormalised: The initial few months were a blur. Physics, Chemistry, Maths – all at once. My school grades started slipping. I remember barely passing my half-yearly exams with a 60%. Mom was worried; Dad kept saying, "It's an investment." We even consulted a career counsellor who suggested trying for other exams like BITSAT or VITEEE, but JEE was the ultimate goal, you see.
normalised: The initial few months were a blur. Physics, Chemistry, Maths – all at once. My school grades started slipping. I remember barely passing my half-yearly exams with a sixty percent. Mom was worried; Dad kept saying, "It's an investment." We even consulted a career counselor who suggested trying for other exams like B-I-T-S-A-T or V-I-T-E-E-E, but J-E-E was the ultimate goal, you see.

unnormalised: By class 12th, things got intense. Sharma Tutorials added extra classes on Sundays and holidays. We had mock tests every week. My rank was consistently around 500 out of 2000 students. Not great, not terrible. I remember one particularly tough test on 20/01/2018 where I scored only 120/360. I was so demotivated, I almost gave up.
normalised: By class twelfth, things got intense. Sharma Tutorials added extra classes on Sundays and holidays. We had mock tests every week. My rank was consistently around five hundred out of two thousand students. Not great, not terrible. I remember one particularly tough test on twentieth January two thousand and eighteen where I scored only one hundred and twenty divided by three hundred and sixty. I was so demotivated, I almost gave up.

unnormalised: But Mr. Sharma sir wouldn't let me. He'd say, "Rohan, beta, IIT is not the only option. There are NITs, IIITs, and even state engineering colleges. Focus on learning, not just cracking the exam." He was right, of course. The pressure was getting to me. I started practicing yoga and meditation for 30 minutes every morning. It helped a bit.
normalised: But Mister Sharma sir wouldn't let me. He'd say, "Rohan, beta, I-I-T is not the only option. There are N-I-T-s, I-I-I-T-s, and even state engineering colleges. Focus on learning, not just cracking the exam." He was right, of course. The pressure was getting to me. I started practicing yoga and meditation for thirty minutes every morning. It helped a bit.

unnormalised: Finally, the big day arrived: JEE Main on 08/04/2019. The exam centre was 2 hours away, so we left home at 6:00 AM. I remember feeling a mix of anxiety and excitement. I attempted around 70 out of 90 questions. Felt okay-ish. Then came the wait for the results.
normalised: Finally, the big day arrived: J-E-E Main on eighth April two thousand and nineteen. The exam center was two hours away, so we left home at six A-M. I remember feeling a mix of anxiety and excitement. I attempted around seventy out of ninety questions. Felt okay-ish. Then came the wait for the results.

unnormalised: The result came out, and I scored a rank of 25000. Not good enough for IIT, but good enough for NIT. I got into NIT Allahabad for Mechanical Engineering. It wasn't my dream branch or my dream college, but it was a decent outcome. Sharma Sir was proud.
normalised: The result came out, and I scored a rank of twenty five thousand. Not good enough for I-I-T, but good enough for N-I-T. I got into N-I-T Allahabad for Mechanical Engineering. It wasn't my dream branch or my dream college, but it was a decent outcome. Sharma Sir was proud.

unnormalised: Looking back, coaching classes were a mixed bag. They provided structure, discipline, and a competitive environment. But they also added immense pressure and stress. Would I do it again? Maybe. But I’d also focus on my mental health and explore other options. The important thing is to learn and grow, regardless of where you end up. And remember, engineering is not the only path to success! There's also medicine, design, arts, and so much more! Just find what you are passionate about.
